properties.why: A more relax destination compared to the Lisbon area.
properties.whyNot: Gets very busy in summer with tourism. Might be more of a retiree destination.

properties.why: Good weather, a nature lover's dream as it has both beaches and mountains.
properties.whyNot: Kinda remote if you want to do weekend trips, only Morocco is really close by.

properties.why: A relatively big island, in one of Europe's most beautiful countries, as well as the cradle of history! The island has a well-established expat community, particularly in areas like Chania and Rethymno.
properties.whyNot: Apparently pretty underwhelming in healthcare and schooling.

properties.why: Because James Bond was here! Pretty big expat community.
Has everything the global traveller wants, given the very international audience visiting this island.
properties.whyNot: Pricey in high season. Not a well known destination for remote workers, rather for partying.

properties.why: Bigger than it's neighbour Ibiza.
Beautiful beaches, great weather all year around. Lower cost of living, pretty decent infrastracture to live as a family. Good international schools.
The digital nomad dream, also for digital nomads with families. The Silicon Valley for the remote entrepreneur?
properties.whyNot: Getting overcrowded, pricey, and air pollution through burning.

properties.why: Caribean with a Dutch vib.
properties.whyNot: High criminality, pretty remote as it lies in front of Venezuela.
Probably a lot of retirees rather than vibrant, young families with children. But that's only an opinion.
Too many tourists and retirees, rather than hipster remote workers.

properties.why: Silicon Valley in the Caribbean? This place is getting popular with Silicon Valley types.
Nice weather, nice beaches, nice nature, good food and a big community of foreigners. Big city nearby with international airport.
properties.whyNot: Getting very popular which raises prices. Part of the Lisbon suburbs which brings city problems (traffic, criminality, ...).

properties.why: Known for it's fantastic food.
properties.whyNot: Very hot in summer. Well-known retiree destination for most north-european seniors.

properties.why: Great education, low criminality, progressive administration.
properties.whyNot: The language is not like any other European langauge.
reviews:
Pros:

Living in the capital city you don't need a car - a monthly bus-pass covers all the metro/tram/bus trips you need for €50 or so.

The city is also very walkable, which is particularly good for children.

If you have children they can go to daycare from 1 year old, and the cost of that is subsidized, they start school properly at age of 7 and generally take themselves there (mostly by walking, some might cycle or take a bus).

The cities are safe, the houses are expensive but not out of reach, and renting isn't so bad, most buildings have double/triple glazing and are very well insulated.

Nature is easy to reach, and readily appreciated. Children spend a couple of hours outdoors at school, even in the winters.

Also if you do get cold a sauna is a great way to warm up!

Lots of technology companies, relative to the city of the country, and English is frequently the working language.

Cons:

The winters get cold, it has been -10°C for the past week, and it will get colder soon enough.

The winters are also dark.

As a UK-native the language is complex and alien, but willingness to learn and practice is appreciated - the con is that if you struggle to order something in broken Finnish people will usually switch to English, which helps you in the short-term, but screws you over in the long term.

Alcoholism is common, and winter depression, but the alcoholism in Scotland is significantly worse so don't go expecting something crazy.

Source

properties.why: The country of Lego, need I say more?
Stockholm gets more than 2000 hours of sunlight yearly, which is a lot for a city north of the Alps (Source).
Because of the sunny weather, because Switzerland overall is a safe place to live with children, because it's amazing for doing outdoor adventures with your kids
properties.whyNot: You need deep pockets! It doesn't seem that there is a tight-knit community of tech-bros there.

properties.why: Nice weather, most walkable country in south East Asia, great public transport, great connections to everywhere in the world, great parks, many playgrounds, many expat families with children, …
properties.whyNot: You need deep pockets. Almost everyone lives in condos, rather than houses, which is less ideal for pets. Could suffer from air pollution in Q4

properties.why: Islands are always fun.
properties.whyNot: Politically pretty complicated with the Turkish claims, I don't know how much of an impact it has on the day to day.

properties.why: A car-free village (source)
Growing community of expats
High standard of living
Active expat community
